title.narrative: PIMS 4113 FSP Improving Enrgy Eff in Industry in Turkey

description.narrative: PIMS-4113: Improving energy efficiency in Industry in Turkey

title.narrative: Midterm evaluation for Improving Energy Efficiency in Industry in Turkey
PIMS 4113 FSP Improving Enrgy Eff in Industry in Turkey
PIMS 4113 FSP Improving Enrgy Eff in Industry in Turkey
PIMS 4113 FSP Improving Enrgy Eff in Industry in Turkey
PIMS 4113 FSP Improving Enrgy Eff in Industry in Turkey

description.narrative: PIMS-4113: Improving energy efficiency in Industry in Turkey
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: To improve energy efficiency of the Turkish industry by enabling and encouraging companies in the industrial sector for efficient management of energy use by different energy conservation measures and energy efficient technologies.

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

To improve energy efficiency of the Turkish industry by enabling and encouraging companies in the industrial sector for efficient management of energy use by different energy conservation measures and energy efficient technologies
A) Energy savings from EE investments in industrial sector compared to baseline

comment.narrative: Technical energy savings potential in industry estimated at around 20%
At least 190 GWh per year (energy and fuel)

Initially anticipated energy savings numbers were reviewed as the analytical part of the baseline study that could not be completed before. To undertake this task, a consultant was hired. The consultant elaborated on the baseline energy consumption patterns of the industrial sub-sectors. By using both top down and bottom up approaches (both energy intensity and specific energy consumption data) he recalculated all the baseline data. Relying on this method and the revised past data, he also fulfilled energy consumption forecasts. The findings were shared with/appreciated by all project partners. The consultant is currently developing alternative scenarios to calculate the possible energy and CO2 savings through the project activities.
No actual energy savings to date. Energy savings from EE investments will be measured after the other activities of the project will result in actual investments. There are some means for this aim such as i) energy audits, ii) developing energy management units in organized industrial zones, iii) technical expert-level trainings in which industrial companies attend for establishing energy management system in their facilities. On those 3 topics there are certain progress: i) The pilot audit program was initiated. ii) The OIZs were selected and equipment tender is ongoing. iii) The call for expert-level training was completed, and the dates were determined. Despite all mentioned progress, a little more time is needed to see the actual investments.
It is possible there were some investments resulting from the initial EnMS training; however those savings would most likely be minimal at this point.

description.narrative: B) Direct and indirect emission reductions

comment.narrative: GHG emissions from industry were around 66.5 MktCO2 in 2009 and are projected to grow to 115.3 MtCO2 by 2025

Direct emission reduction (associated with demo projects) of 60.9 ktCO2 p.a. and (assuming an average 10-year lifetime of energy investment) 609 ktCO2 cumulatively
Cumulative indirect emission reduction due to projectâ€™s capacity building activities ranging from 1.8 MtCO2 (bottom-up approach) to 32.7 MtCO2 (top-down)

No actual emission savings to date. Emission savings from EE investments will be measured after the other activities of the project will result in actual investments. There are some means for this aim such as i) energy audits, ii) developing energy management units in organized industrial zones, iii) technical expert-level trainings in which industrial companies attend for establishing energy management system in their facilities. On those 3 topics there are certain progress: i) The pilot audit program was initiated. ii) The OIZs were selected and equipment tender is ongoing. iii) The call for expert-level training was completed, and the dates were determined. Despite all mentioned progress, a little more time is needed to see the actual investments.
ISO 50001 and Energy Management System trainings are likely to play a significant role for reducing indirect emissions. These trainings would be supportive to take action for reducing energy use by simple measures, which do not entail serious investments. More information on EnMS trainings is given in part of outcome-2.

description.narrative: Direct and indirect emission reductions

comment.narrative: GHG emissions from industry were around 66.5 MktCO2 in 2009 and are projected to grow to 115.3 MtCO2 by 2025

Direct emission reduction (associated with demo projects) of 60.9 ktCO2 p.a. and (assuming an average 10-year lifetime of energy investment) 609 ktCO2 cumulatively
Cumulative indirect emission reduction due to projectâ€™s capacity building activities ranging from 1.8 MtCO2 (bottom-up approach) to 32.7 MtCO2 (top-down)

description.narrative: Energy Management Unit

comment.narrative: Not Available
10 Energy Management Unit will be established in the selected pilot OIZ (Organised Industry Zones)
New Financial Mechanisms for Energy Efficiency in Industry

description.narrative: Strengthened institutional-regulatory framework and a national Energy Management Standard contributing to the implementation of the EE Law
C) The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

comment.narrative: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs

New provisions available (EnMS)
Institutions strengthened and cooperation increased between EIE, KOSGEB, TTGV and OIZs

1) For strengthening the data flow between partner organizations (specifically YEGM and KOSGEB), there are plans to create a new data collection, processing and reporting system. It has also been decided to integrate the databases of partner organizations so that they could monitor the developments in different industrial sub-sectors simultaneously. To reach this end, an RFP has been prepared. For announcing the tender, the final approval has been requested.

description.narrative: The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

comment.narrative: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs

New provisions available (EnMS)
Institutions strengthened and cooperation increased between EIE, KOSGEB, TTGV and OIZs

2) The second phase of the financial study was started in the first quarter of 2014. What Turkish project partners highlighted was to see a tailor-made design by considering Turkey’s own conditions. The major developments taken place during the PIR period are summarized below:
2.a) The consultant prepared and proposed a new financial mechanisms for TTGV. Overall, TTGV was satisfied with the study and output. Consequently, TTGV incorporated the findings and proposal into its financing methodology for funding EE investments.
2.b) The consultant presented his initial draft proposal for KOSGEB in September 2014. KOSGEB evaluated the proposal and requested additional mathematical analysis in November 2014. The consultant delivered the final study in January 2015. KOSGEB was satisfied with the final delivery and created a new funding mechanism in the light of the consultant’s work. The new funding mechanism was submitted to the top management of the KOSGEB. The top management principally appreciated the idea. Yet, beginning from March 2015 both top and middle level managers of KOSGEB were changed. Therefore, the realization of the new mechanism was postponed. Unless no more changes happen in the management level, the mechanism is expected to be discussed in September-2015.
2.c) The consultant began evaluating the YEGM support mechanisms and forming a new integrated financial mechanism. He drafted the YEGM study in March 2015; however, the PMU asked for some revisions of the draft and sent it back to the consultant with necessary feedback. He is currently working on it. The consultant elaborated on the integrated mechanism in parallel and submitted his studies in April 2015. At the beginning of June 2015 a meeting was held in Ankara and the proposed mechanism was discussed in detail. The basic ideas were appreciated and the consultant was asked to revise his draft in order to strengthen some of the components.

description.narrative: The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

comment.narrative: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs

New provisions available (EnMS)
Institutions strengthened and cooperation increased between EIE, KOSGEB, TTGV and OIZs

3) For introducing and promoting energy Management System (EnMS), several training sessions were held in different locations of Turkey. Industry managers, OIZ personnel, engineers, university professors, energy consultants and certification company employees participated in the trainings. The places, number of participants and the types of the trainings, which were held during the PIR period (including May and June 2014), are summarized below:
User Level:
Istanbul-1: 26
Istanbul-2: 27
Ankara-1: 23
Ankara-2: 41
Gaziantep: 23
Kayseri: 16
Izmir: 58
Bursa: 44
Denizli: 63
Adana: 29
Konya: 53
Training of Trainers:
Istanbul: 38
Ankara: 28
In summary, approximately 400 people were trained.

description.narrative: The content and status of new policies and programs supporting their implementation

comment.narrative: Insufficient implementation of policies and programs

New provisions available (EnMS)
Institutions strengthened and cooperation increased between EIE, KOSGEB, TTGV and OIZs

4) Establishing and developing Energy Management Units (EMUs) in the OIZs is of crucial importance as these units will contribute to industrial companies within the borders of industrial zones to create awareness, to enhance the capacity, to promote energy audits, and to propose simple measures for investment. The milestones for this activity are summarized below:
4.a) In July 2014 an invitation letter together with a questionnaire were prepared and sent to 103 OIZs. Even though there are 272 OIZ licenses were authorized, some of them are not active as of now. Some of those who are active do not have more than 50 companies operating in the boundary. Even though Turkish legislation mandates to establish EMUs in OIZs whose total number of companies exceed 50, all eligible OIZs were invited to gather as much data as possible.
4.b) In September 2014 the applications were classified and analyzed. In October 2014, by the participation of the project partners, 9 OIZs were initially selected. It was decided to visit all selected OIZs to see their potential and availability to implement the program.
4.c) In November and December 2014 all 9 OIZs were visited. They were informed about the IEEI project, the data they submitted were checked, their physical facilities and human resources were examined.
4.d) In the final evaluation undertaken in January 2015, 3 of the initially selected OIZs were eliminated due to their insufficient capacity.
4.e) In February 2015, an official letter was sent to the remaining 6 OIZs. In the letter, the OIZs were requested to sign the commitment form to undertake the joint program. They all committed to cooperate and dedicate necessary resources.
4.f) In April 2015, a tender was announced by UNIDO for purchasing a set of basic equipment for the OIZs: an infrared camera (together with software for reporting), infrared temperature meter, ultrasonic liquid meter, energy analyzer (including data logger, cable, connector, clamps, and a suitable evaluation software), multifunction HVAC and indoor air quality meter (together with probes), flue gas analyzer, ultrasonic leak detector, tachometer, and water conductivity meter. The bid collection ended in May 2015. The evaluation still continues. Just after the procurement of the measuring devices, the program will be accelerated.

description.narrative: Enhanced capacity and awareness of Turkish industry and energy service providers
D) Additional number of EE projects investment made by industrial companies per year

comment.narrative: N/A
About 200 EE investment directly (demos) or indirectly (outcome 2; capacity building)
The studies for increasing the number of investments in industrial EE are ongoing. The actual data will be gathered next year.

description.narrative: E) Expanded business opportunities for ESCOs

comment.narrative: No performance contracts concluded by ESCOs to date
At least 10 new performance contracts concluded by ESCOs per year

Removing this indicator was suggested in Midterm Review (Evaluation) Report, and accordingly the issue was drawn to the attention of 2014 PSC (project steering committee) meeting. In the 2014 PSC meeting, this suggestion was rejected. However, the PMU insisted that this indicator should be removed from the Project. In 2015 PSC meeting the issue was discussed again and removal proposal was approved by the committee. In the new project design, it is not an indicator any more.
Improving the awareness level of energy efficiency in relevant parties.

1) Awareness raising meetings were integrated with EnMS trainings. Beginning in September 2015, expert level training will be held for selected industrial companies. To determine these companies, an official invitation letter was sent to 145 prominent industrial plants, which were engaged in user level trainings, to join the program. The applications are still taken.
Upgrading of intranet and extranet web portals

2) The project web page was activated. Compilation of case studies for enriching the web page is underway.
3) A set of EE tips for SMEs were prepared. After acceptance by KOSGEB, they will be transformed into leaflets and circulated to the SMEs. For the beginning, 10 different topics were determined and elaborated. It is planned to increase the number of leaflets according to the feedback of the SMEs. The tips will also be distributed through participating OIZs.
4) Upgrading the Intranet and extranet EE web portals of YEGM and KOSGEB will commence after the completion of the Database Management task, which is, in effect, the prerequisite of this activity.
5) A huge translation and editing activity is ongoing. The aim is to submit technical training materials to YEGM, which will later train industrial facilities, ESCOs, universities, and chambers. Up to now 354 pages of Word document and 757 pages of PowerPoint document were finalized in “pumps” package. Currently, the translation of the “fans” package is underway. It is expected to submit more than 1000 pages material in July 2015. Then the materials for compressed air, steam and electrical motors will be handled.
6) The “Practical Guide for EnMS” prepared by UNIDO was translated into Turkish and 5000 copies were printed. It was (and will be) used as a training material in EE activities. It was circulated to the relevant industrial facilities, associations, ESCOs and financial institutions.
7) For review of ESCO experience and conducting a gap analysis, it was planned to recruit an international consultant. For this aim, the ToR has recently been drafted and submitted to NPD for his approval. It is expected to be announced in July 2015.
8) For enhancing the capacity of ESCOs (they are called EVD companies in the relevant legislation), a 3-day training course was carried in November 2014. The dishwasher factory of one of Turkey’s prominent manufacturers, Arcelik, was visited and audited by the participation of the representatives of 9 EVD companies, which were certified by YEGM to undertake energy audits. The actual implementation was later discussed and the results as well as approaches were criticized by the international consultants.
9) The study for producing 10 short training films (steam traps, compressed air, pumps, fans, boilers, furnaces, refrigeration systems, lighting systems, drying systems, insulation) and one generic film on EE in industry (through introducing the training center of YEGM) with English subtitles has been initiated. The contractor is currently working on designing the scenarios. The video shooting process is planned to begin in July 2015.

description.narrative: Energy audit program for large industry and SMEs implemented
F) Share of energy audits in Turkey leading to actual investments in EE in industry

comment.narrative: Less than 10% (to be verified and adjusted within 1st project year)
At least 50%

1) An audit checklist (including around 80 questions about boilers, pumps, compressed air, etc.), prepared by project consultants, was finalized by the contribution of the YEGM experts, who had considerable experience in undertaking energy audits in the field. The checklist is ready to use for walk through energy audits, particularly in the utilities and general systems of the factories. The checklist was used during the training of the ESCOs (EVD companies) and the audit of the Arcelik plant.
2) The checklist will be supplemented by more detailed material for certain energy-intensive processes, especially in iron steel, cement, ceramics, paper and pulp, and chemicals industries. To find a competent company having experts in these fields, an RFP was prepared and submitted to the NPD for his approval in April 2015. The tender is expected to be announced in August 2015.
3) Within the context of the developing of an audit methodology, the EE auditing guide (including audit report template, basic principles, etc.) was developed and modified according to ISO 50002, which was issued in June 2014.
4) Energy Audits: The pilot phase of the energy audit activities was started in February 2015. Nine industrial facilities out of 51, which had previously been invited by GDRE officially, applied to be a part of the auditing program. Necessary background information of participating industrial companies for the bidding process such as energy consumption, production processes, the capacity of electricity transformers, features of steam systems, number of compressors, motors, etc. was collected by YEGM and the bidding process was initiated in January 2015. Seven eligible EVD companies were invited to bid. Six of them submitted their proposals on time. The contracting was finalized in February 2015 and the pre-audits (walk through energy audits (WTEAs)) were realized in March 2015. The WTEA reports were collected in April 2015. In May 2015, the evaluation committee held a 2 day meeting to assess the 9 reports. Letters providing the feedback from the evaluation committee were sent to the EVD companies. The EVD companies revised the reports and submitted the modified versions in June 2015. They were all re-evaluated and accepted. The EVD companies are now undertaking detailed energy audits. After the evaluation of the detailed energy audit reports, the new audit program will be designed in the light of lessons learned.
5) For further audits there will be a call for proposal including feasibility study supports. In this call for proposal the industrial companies will be invited to join the program for i) audits, ii) feasibility studies by committing that they will produce “investment projects”, which will also later be supported by the YEGM. The preparations studies are ongoing for this program.

description.narrative: G) Additional energy saving investment opportunities identified as part of energy audits

comment.narrative: Zero
At least 190 GWh/year in new EE investments identified

After the finalization of the pilot audit program, the potential for investments will be clarified. With further audits, more opportunities will arise for energy saving. Direct contribution to the feasibility studies of the investment projects will also be provided throughout the call for proposal.

description.narrative: G) Additional energy saving investment opportunities identified as part of energy audits

comment.narrative: Zero
At least 190 GWh/year in new EE Investments identified

description.narrative: State-of-the-art energy management practices and EE measures, business and financing models are demonstrated
H) Improved specific energy consumption by demonstration projects

comment.narrative: SEC in demonstration projects is at country-average level
SEC in demonstration projects improved on average by at least 10%

No specific investment has been undertaken during the PIR period. The visible results of this outcome will be realized beginning from the year of 2016 as the demo projects will be created according to the results of audits, EnMS trainings and feasibility studies, which will be supported through the call for proposal.

description.narrative: Monitoring and evaluation; knowledge sharing and info dissemination
(no indicators under this outcome; see IP sheet for outputs)

comment.narrative: N/A - no activity has been undertaken during the PIR period in this outcome.

title.narrative: PIMS 3646: Promoting Energy Efficiency in Buildings

description.narrative: PIMS-3646: Promoting Energy Efficiency in Buildings

title.narrative: Midterm Evaluation for Promoting Energy Efficiency in Buildings
PIMS 3646: Promoting Energy Efficiency in Buildings
PIMS 3646: Promoting Energy Efficiency in Buildings
PIMS 3646: Promoting Energy Efficiency in Buildings
PIMS 3646: Promoting Energy Efficiency in Buildings
PIMS 3646 CC FSP EE in Buildin

description.narrative: PIMS-3646: Promoting Energy Efficiency in Buildings
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: To reduce energy consumption and associated GHG emissions in public buildings in Turkey by raising building energy performance standards, improving enforcement of building codes, enhancing building energy management and introducing the use of integrated building design approach.

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

To reduce energy consumption and associated GHG emissions in buildings in Turkey by raising building energy performance standards, improving enforcement of building codes, enhancing building energy management and introducing the use of an integrated building design approach
Average total energy consumption (for heating, cooling, ventilation and lighting) in new residential and non-residential buildings

comment.narrative:
Residential: 200 kWh/m ²/year
Non-residential: 321 kWh/m ²/year
Non-residential: 193 kWh/m ²/year for buildings built with IBDA

A total of five buildings designed according to the Integrated Building Design Approach were simulated for building energy performances. The results achieved were far behind the targets. For the Sincan-Etimesgut Departments of Land Registry and Cadastre Office Building, 37.32kWh/m2/yr were achieved whereas for Cezeri Green Technologies High School the result was 23.62 kWh/m2/yr. The construction of the buildings were started and the total energy consumptions will be measured.
Moreover, to achive this objective, a Terms of Reference were prepared for developing New Minimum Building Energy Performance Standard (MBEPS) and Nearly Zero Energy Building (nZEB) Approach for Turkey.
In order to increase the awareness regarding the building codes in Turkey, a book, prepared by IEA and UNDP, was translated to Turkish.

description.narrative: Cumulative CO2 emission reductions from new buildings to be built during project lifetime (2010-2015) against the baseline

comment.narrative: 0 tCO2
2 million tCO2

Within the scope of the project, 5 different buildings were designed using the Integrated Building Design Approach (IBDA). These buildings consist of 1 office building for Ministry of Environment and Urbanism and 4 buildings (school, workshop, dormitory, sports hall) for the Ministry of National Education. Tender documents were prepared for both Ministries and tendering procedures were completed by the Ministry of Environment and Urbanism in December 2014 and construction works are ongoing. Tendering procedures were completed by the Ministry of National Education in January 2015 and construction works are also ongoing. The total project direct emission reductions resulting from the construction of 5 demonstration buildings (around 30,000 m2 construction area) are estimated to be around 29,705 tCO2eq over a 20-year period. In order to reach the 2m tCO2eq emission reduction target, design and construction of 67 buildings following the IBDA approach will be adequate. This is easily achievable provided that the use of IBDA for new public buildings is adopted by the Government of Turkey.
The Ministry of Environment and Urbanism is highly interested in adaptation and implementation of IBDA and thereby its integration to the building by-laws. 3 books were pepared for the adaptation and implementation of IBDA in Turkey by 15 experts and the final editing works are ongoing. Complementary trainings on the use of IBDA and partnerships with selected universities for promoting IBDA are planned. Later, a strategy will also be developed to make IBDA mandatory for new public buildings.

description.narrative: Cumulative CO2 emission reductions from new buildings to be built during project lifetime (2010-2015) againist the baseline

comment.narrative: 0 tCO2
2 million tCO2

description.narrative: Improved energy efficiency in new and existing buildings through stronger regulations, institutions and implementers
The content and status of new policies, programs, and implementers supporting implementation of EE and RE in buildings

comment.narrative: Legislation, institutions, and implementers to support enhancement of building energy efficiency needs to be strengthened
New legal and regulatory provisions, strengthened institutions, and better supporting compliance checking, enforcement and outreach programs adopted for enhanced EE in new buildings

Once the “Energy Efficiency in New Buildings Checklist and Guidebook” document was completed, 4 regional training sessions were organized and completed in June 2014 in order to promote energy efficiency in new buildings. More than 600 participants were attended and to increase the number of people to reach the document and the trainings, an online training module was developed and uploaded to the website of the Ministry of Environment and Urbanism under Building Inspection System (www.yds.gov.tr). The Ministry is currently working on the checklist to integrate into the legislation. Once this checklist is integrated into "Building Inspection legislation”, it will be mandatory to apply the checklist for all new private building project designs and consecutively in constructions. This is more or less equal to 100.000 new buildings every year.
A new RFP document was prepared and will be launched in July 2015, for the development of Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) for new buildings and adaptation of Near Zero Energy Buildings (nZEB) for Turkey and energy efficiency strategy document for buildings.

description.narrative: Cost-effective energy efficiency solutions showcased through integrated building design approach application in two demo buildings

Adoption and diffusion level of IBDA
Implementation of IBDA demonstration constructions

comment.narrative: Limited knowledge and application of IBDA

Cost effective energy efficiency solutions are demonstrated through IBDA demonstration buildings
IBDA is promoted through trainings and awareness raising activities

For the 5 different demo buildings, the designs were completed and approved by the respective Ministries (Ministry of Environment and Urbanization for the office building and Ministry of National Education for school buildings (school, atelier workshop, dormitory and sports hall)). The tendering procedures were completed and the construction works have been initialized by the Ministry of Environment and Urbanization for the office building in December 2014. For the school buildings, the tendering procedures were completed and the construction works have been initialized by the Ministry of National Education in January 2015. Monitoring and Consultancy services in order to provide correct implementation of the project design are ongoing. Several visits to the construction site have been accomplished and the construction is closely followed up.
Energy Performance Certificates (A level Energy Performance Certificates for all buildings) from the BEP-TR program (a public issued building energy performance software) were received and Life Cycle Cost Analysis Reports for the demo buildings were produced. The simulated energy performances for office building and for school buildings are 37 kWh/m2/yr and 23 kWh/m2/yr respectively.
Life Cycle Cost Analysis Reports for the demo buildings were prepared according to the approximate cost values and the payback period for the office building was found to be around 6 years and the payback period for the school buildings was found to be around 13 years. When the life cycle cost analysis were repeated with the actual costs of the buildings accoring to the bid amounts, the payback period for the office building was found to be around 4.5 years.
A team of 15 experts for promotion of IBDA through preparation of an "Adaptation Report" and an "Implementation Guidebook" was established. The team has produced 3 books with an addition of “Priorities and Targets for the Building Performance” book. All the books are reviewed several times by the experts of the Ministries and comments were received. Editing works are ongoing and printing versions are being prepared for all the three books.
Complimentary training activities and cooperation with selected universities are also planned for October 2015. The real impact of this outcome is directly related to the adoption level of IBDA by the Government. The performance levels of IBDA demonstration buildings are impressive. The user behavior and its effect on performance are yet to be seen following the completion of demonstration buildings. The performance will be monitored when the operation phase starts.

description.narrative: New tools developed and introduced to facilitate compliance with higher energy efficiency standards and application of integrated building design approach in buildings
Monitoring and verification processes are in place and disseminated effectively among key stakeholders

comment.narrative:
No monitoring system for building energy performance
No analysis tool for RE in new buildings
Training materials need significant upgrading

New tools are developed for analysis and monitoring purposes, financial mechanisms
Training materials revised/developed
Existing websites and tools updated

A tender document was prepared in order to develop an economic analysis (feasibility) tool for the use of renewable energy technologies (RET-EAT) during the design of new buildings. The tender was carried out, however due to budget constraints, the tender was cancelled in July 2014. Revisions were made in the RFP and the tendering process was repeated in January 2015. Seven bids were received and the contract was signed in May 2015 with the successful tenderer. The kick-off meeting were organized in June 2015 and the activity is ongoing.
For the development/revision of the training materials on energy management and energy auditing for buildings, communications and assessments with the legal entities and the ministry are ongoing. The requirements were listed and possible ways to have them prepared are being searched.

description.narrative: Building energy consumption, energy savings, and other results of the project monitored, evaluated, and reported
The status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability

comment.narrative: Insufficient institutional mechanisms in place to ensure sustainability of project results
Project recommendations to ensure institutional sustainability adopted

In order to contribute to the institutional stability in terms of building energy performance, developing New Minimum Building Energy Performance Standard (MBEPS) for Turkey, and Developing Near-Zero-Energy Building (nZEB) Approach for Turkey is an important step and is ongoing. Several trainings were accomplished and new trainings are being planned.
Besides, a communications strategy for effective dissemination of project results and improved awareness raising activities is also developed.
A launching meeting is being organized for the demo buildings.
New brochures for the integrated design approach key issues has been prepared and published. Ministry of Environment and Urbanism distributed the brochures (approximately #5000) in their service trainings and will go on sharing the brochures prepared by our project.

description.narrative: In line with 2006 National Rural Development Strategy, Ardahan-Kars-Artvin Development Project (AKADP) aims to reduce rural poverty in the Provinces of Ardahan, Kars and Artvin.
ARDAHAN KARS ARTVIN DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division

policy, planning and administration
Dissemination of E-Consulate Module for Increased Efficiency in Service Delivery for of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs
MFA E-Consulate
capital of a political entity

title.narrative: Uti. REN. ENR. & INC. ENR. EFF. IN SEAR - PHASE 2

title.narrative: PIMS 4434: Integrated Appr. to Man. of Forests in Turkey

description.narrative: Integrated Approach to Management of Forests in Turkey, with Demonstration in High Conservation Value Forests in the Mediterranean Region

title.narrative: PIMS 4434: Integrated Appr. to Man. of Forests in Turkey
PIMS 4434: Integrated Appr. to Man. of Forests in Turkey
PIMS 4434: Integrated Appr. to Man. of Forests in Turkey

description.narrative: To promote an integrated approach to management of forests in Turkey, demonstrating multiple environmental benefits in high conservation value forests in the Mediterranean forest region
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: the project will demonstrate approaches to generating, measuring, reporting on and verifying carbon, biodiversity and socio-economic benefits generated through this integrated approach at five Mediterranean forest sites (over a total area of 450,000 ha).

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration
To promote an integrated approach to management of forests in Turkey, demonstrating multiple environmental benefits in high conservation value forests in the Mediterranean forest region
Area of forest landscapes in Turkey with integrated forest- plans developed and under implementation that deliver multiple environmental benefits (biodiversity, climate change), ha.

comment.narrative: 0.45 mln ha

Project initiated several activities at site level and headquarter level to enable the legislative and organisational structure for ensuring integration at landscape level. While the target level at end of the project (i.e. 0.45 mln ha) will be achieved through cumulative effect of all progress at each outcomes, current contribution of outcomes is promising with several facts as following; (i) LULUCF unit established and MRV action plan prepared (ii) Process for amending legislation and site based activities are in line for producing technical and policy level justifications, (iii) site based interventions for mitigation activities (i.e. fire and pest management, solar water heating systems), and enhancement of carbon stocks (silvicultural activities) are detailed in an integrated approach at 1/25.000 maps, (iv) rapid biodiversity assessment at all pilot sites started (some taxa already mapped) along with silvicultural implementation plans.

description.narrative: Policy and institutional framework for integrated forest management within landscape
LULUCF Unit

comment.narrative: No properly capacitated LULUCF Unit in the Government
One adequately staffed and funded LULUCF unit with technical capacities to drive forest carbon efforts forward in the country

One adequately staffed and funded LULUCF unit established. Capacity needs assessment is under implementation. List of names, roles and responsibilities, and organisational structure are modified according to project needs. LULUCF Unit already started their works on INDC, calculation of LULUCF sector and other related works in according to the requests from the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation, and Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Role of LULUCF Unit on forest based MRV and NAMA identified. Upon capacity enhancement activities, LULUCF Unit will lead the MRV and NAMA related activities.

description.narrative: Forest protected area regulatory framework

comment.narrative: No legal framework defining forest PA expansion and integration within broader landscape
Effective regulatory framework enables GDF to establish forest PAs based on combined SFM criteria, including biodiversity and carbon

The GDF and related departments identified needs and process for amending regulation on forest PAs. Required data from Component 3 identified to understand the scale and scope of the amendment in the Protected Forests Regulation. It is decided to start the legislative works upon justification of biodiversity conservation needs for permanency and integrity through field surveys in the Pilot sites.

description.narrative: MRV for forest-based mitigation and sequestration

comment.narrative: No MRV
One MRV for forest-based mitigation and sequestration in Turkey is developed, with initial emphasis on Mediterranean region.

A detailed activity plan to deploy MRV for forest-based mitigation and sequestration prepared by the project team, and endorsed by the GDF. LULUCF Unit, academia, and Forest Information System coordinator within GDF have been consulted along with the GoldStandard Foundation. A project cooperation agreement was drafted to undertake activities to prepare MRV starting in the second half of 2015.

description.narrative: Forest sector Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Action (NAMA)

comment.narrative: No NAMA
One fully developed NAMA covering 2-4 million ha Mediterranean-region forests

The Steering Committee and the LULUCF Unit was consulted on the NAMA issue since the position of Turkey on eligibility is under question. As a result of the Steering Committee decision, it was decided to undertake consultation with the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation, the Focal Point of the UNFCCC, to elaborate Turkey's position on NAMA. According to the advise from the Ministry of Environment and Urbanisation, it was decided to wait for official communication from the Secretariat of UNFCCC. Once the official communication will be finalised, the MoEU will share the decision with the Steering Committee and the LULUCF Unit of the GDF.

description.narrative: Implementation of forest-based GHG mitigation and carbon sequestration tools within landscape
Fire management and carbon losses from fires

comment.narrative: Suppression-focused fire management system; annual carbon losses at five pilot sites average 3,629 tCO2/y
Proactive (prevention and load management focussed) fire management methods at pilot sites generate carbon benefits of 1,646 tCO2/y over baseline.

Site based interventions, forest unit based mitigation options, fuel management strategies are elaborated with the Department of Fire Combating, and academia. A detailed plan for integrated fire management system, a list of required equipment, software, and training needs drafted. Terms of Reference for national consultant prepared and an Integrated Fire Management consultant hired. Yearly intervention plans at all pilot sites are under preparation.

description.narrative: Silvicultural methods consider carbon and biodiversity aspects. Assessment of associated carbon benefits.

comment.narrative: Carbon benefits not taken into account or measured; locations not chosen to maximize connectivity enhancements.
Silvicultural approaches at pilot sites generate carbon benefits of 11,572 tCO2/y along with enhanced connectivity.

Locations chosen to maximize connectivity enhancements. As a result of field surveys, a site of 3,919 ha was identified to undertake silvicultural efforts for carbon and biodiversity aspects in 2015. A carbon-focused silviculture consultant and a afforestation consultant were hired. A detailed plan for carbon focused silviculture and afforestation action plan at site level with capacity of carbon stocks were prepared. Activity plan at site level and forest unit level are under preparation.

description.narrative: Fuel wood removals and associated carbon fluxes.

comment.narrative: High levels of legal and illegal fuel wood removals for household consumption, especially home heating, with resulting annual carbon losses at five pilot sites averaging 18,775 tCO2/y. No alterative system to replace fire wood consumption in place.
Expansion of micro-credit program into Mediterranean region generates carbon benefits of 13,038 tCO2/y over baseline

As per the Steering Committee meeting decision and technical workshops with related GDF departments, ORKOY's micro-credit programme will started after a detailed study on socio-economic situation of forest villages within pilot sites and a technology assessment for house heating solar systems including solar water heating system are complete. Terms of Reference for both services prepared and submitted to the GDF.

description.narrative: Integrated pest management (IPM) and associated carbon fluxes

comment.narrative: No proactive IPM, resulting annual carbon losses at five pilot sites averaging 45,286 tCO2/y.
Introduction of IPM methods and establishment of two pest centres generates carbon benefits of 30,191 tCO2/y over baseline.

Location of two pest centres identified. Required activities for equipping and running of pest centres with laboratories and early warning system are in progress. Site based interventions, pest-specific action plans, data management of integrated pest management strategy are elaborated with the Department of Pest Management. A list of required equipment, and training needs drafted. A national Integrated Pest Management Consultant was hired. Yearly intervention plans at all pilot sites are under preparation.

description.narrative: Carbon protocols designed and completed before, during and after implementation of enhancement and mitigation efforts

comment.narrative: No carbon protocol

Introduction of carbon protocols in line with MRV system (Output 1.3) enabling integration of climate change into forest management plans through a central LULUCF Database under Forest Information System (FIS) Project of GDF.

Terms of reference for a national consultant on forest management plans, and a national consultant on carbon protocols are prepared and submitted to the GDF. Upon technical inputs from the related departments, the consultants will be hired. ENVANIS system to be upgraded for carbon protocols has been elaborated through several technical workshops and meetings with the Forest Management and Planning Department of the GDF. 1/25.000 scale maps of all pilot sites with current forest management functions prepared, overlapped with biodiversity data, along with fire, pest, silviculture, afforestation action plans. A process for ecosystem base multi-functional planning with specific table and optimal situation for climate change and biodiversity was drafted.

description.narrative: Strengthening protection of high conservation value forests in Mediterranean landscape
Extent of forest PAs

comment.narrative: Mediterranean forest habitats are under-represented in national PA system
Effective protection extended to 79,960 ha, including under-represented Mediterranean forest habitats.

Identification of 79,960 ha "Protected Forests" through rapid biodiversity assessment and integration into forest management plans of 5 sites started. Biodiversity rapid assessment for 6 taxa (large mammals, small mammals, birds, herpetofauna, butterflies, plants) and ecological assessment within all pilot sites under implementation with involvement of several academia, forest directorate officials at site level and biodiversity branch of the GDF. Identification of silvicultural activities in line with biodiversity targets underpinned by rapid assessment carried out in 5 pilot sites. Preparation of Forest Biodiversity strategy and action plan for GDF, including national and local capacity assessment studies have been elaborated with the GDF. Upon discussions, it was decided to undertake such activities on capacity assessment next year, upon obtaining results of the ongoing rapid assessment. Two books on biodiversity and forest management prepared and published for forest engineers at national and local level.

description.narrative: PA management effectiveness: METT Score

comment.narrative:
Aladaglar National Parks - 35 METT Score
Kartal Lake Nature Reserve - 21 METT score

Aladaglar National Parks - 40 METT Score
Kartal Lake Nature Reserve - 40 METT score

Aladaglar National Parks - 35 METT Score
Kartal Lake Nature Reserve - 21 METT Score
The updated scores will be available for the midterm review in 2016.

description.narrative: Improvement in biodiversity indicator species at pilot sites

comment.narrative: See baseline values for pilot sites in table below
See target values for pilot sites in table below

Field studies for all taxa started last year. As of 30 June 2015, consultants are in the field with the forestry officials for the surveys for large mammals, small mammals, birds, herpetofauna, butterflies, and plants. Habitat suitability assessment are also under implementation. 10 orchids identified while one is local endemic (Ophyrs amanensis subsp. antalyansis) in one pilot site. Distribution maps prepared and biodiversity friendly forestry activities drafted.

description.narrative: Carbon benefits from forest Pas

comment.narrative: Areas are subject to regular logging according to management plans, carbon pools diminishing.
Net carbon benefit associated with new conservation areas estimated at 64,245 t CO2e/year.

Biodiversity rapid assessment is under implementation. Initial maps are produced according to biodiversity importance. Final maps with new protected forests will be ready in 2016. According to the final maps and biodiversity requirements, logging schemes will be revised with calculations on net carbon benefits in 2016. All calculations will be in line with MRV system to be developed under Outcome 1.

title.narrative: PIMS 5266 EA First Biennial Report (FBR) to UNFCCC
PIMS 5266 EA First Biennial Report (FBR) to UNFCCC
PIMS 5266 EA First Biennial Report (FBR) to UNFCCC

description.narrative: UNFCCC Decision 2/CP.17, Developed Country Parties are requested to submit their Biennial Reports (BR) to the Secretariat either as an annex to the National Communication (NC) or as a separate report.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Preparation of the First Biennial Report which is expected to enhance general awareness and knowledge on reporting requirements of UNFCCC for Turkey and help in to taking into account in the process of national planning and policy.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration
Turkey's First Biennual Report

comment.narrative: Preparation of Turkey's First Biennual Report to be submitted to UNFCCC as of January 2016. Supporting the development of Turkey's INDC.

•Brief summary of the national circumstances prepared in line with the Sixth National Communication •Institutional arrangements and level of support relevant to the preparation of the national communications and biennial reports on a continuous basis described •A web-site serving as an e-library including all relevant documents, reports and publications, as well as an electronic portal facilitating the preparation of National Communications and Biennial Reports developed and published under MoEU’s web-site •Worksheets, summary tables for GHG emissions elaborated and needs identified for the BR preparation •List of recommendations to strengthen data collection process, institutional coordination and collaboration, reporting and quality of the inventories prepared •FBR Table 1 on GHG Emissions and Trends prepared •Support provided for strengthening national arrangements and raising awareness to enable the preparation of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) •Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) developed by other countries briefly reviewed •Support provided for the identification and drafting of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDC) •FBR Table 5 on summary of key variables and assumptions used in the projections analysis prepared •FBR Table 6 on updated greenhouse gas projections ‘with measures’ and ‘without measures’ scenarios prepared •A study on financial, technological and capacity needs and constraints related to climate change as well as on international and national resources allocated for climate change with their associated effectiveness performed using a participatory approach •Updated information on financial resources, technology transfer, capacity building and technical support received from bilateral and multilateral donors, IFCs, Green Climate Fund (GCF) etc. for activities related to climate change prepared •FBR Table 7 on provision of public financial support prepared •FBR Table 8 on pr

•Information in tabular format consolidated, compiled and First and Second Biennial Reports to UNFCCC submitted and published as of January 2016. •Provision of support provided to the process of establishment of the Measurement, Reporting and Verification arrangements in waste sector. •Provision of assistance provided for the preparation of project proposals to be submitted for international financial resources.
